Award.AwardTitle: Excited-State Properties of Electrostatically Doped Low-Dimensional Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports computational and theoretical research and education to study doping effects on excited-state properties of low-dimensional structures of broad interest, including silicon nanowires, graphene and electrically gated bilayer graphene. Because of the geometry of these structures and the associated divergence of the electronic density of states close to the band edge, electrostatically doped free carriers can dramatically change the electronic screening of many-electron interactions. As a result, an even small amount of doping may substantially change the excited-state properties, such as the quasiparticle band gap and optical properties, making doping an efficient tool to tune the intrinsic electronic structure of low-dimensional materials in addition to its usual role of providing free carriers. The variation of many-electron effects may also modify the spin singlet-triplet splitting which would change the luminescence properties with possible application to quantum information technology. The research involves using density functional theory based methods along with GW and the solution of the Bethe-Salpeter equation.

This award also supports educational activities, including a new course, 'First-Principles Calculations and Their Applications to Nanostructures,' in Washington University. Additional activities include a series of seminars for interested researchers from institutes nearby to introduce cutting-edge first-principles approaches and their applications to the nanotechnology.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports computational and theoretical research and education to investigate the properties of very tiny wires that are little more than a few atoms wide and single-atom thick carbon sheets known as graphene. The PI will use advanced computational methods that aim to predict properties of structures of atoms and materials starting from knowledge of their constituent atoms. Of particular interest are properties that involve how well materials and structures of atoms absorb or emit light. An aim of the work is to determine how the addition and removal electrons from the quantum wires or graphene can be used to design the quantum mechanical states of quantum wires and graphene.

This project contributes to the knowledge base including methods and software upon which future device technologies will be based. Specific aspects of the work contribute to the design of photovoltaic devices for the efficient conversion of light to electricity.
This award also supports educational activities, including a new course, 'First-Principles Calculations and Their Applications to Nanostructures,' in Washington University. Additional activities include a series of seminars for interested researchers from institutes nearby to introduce cutting-edge first-principles approaches and their applications to the nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This awarded proposal focuses on electronic structures and excited-state properties of reduced-dimensional materials. During the past three years, the PI’s group has published around 20 peer-reviewed articles and has achieved important outputs with the NSF support.

 

Intellectual merits: The achievements include both developments of fundamental methodologies and predicting promising applications with developed tools. First, the PI’s group has developed an efficient ab initio approach to accurately calculate the band-gap renormalization in doped two-dimensional (2D) semiconductors, as shown in Figure 1. This study reveals the fundamental mechanism of interactions between quasiparticles and 2D plasmons. Employing this method has satisfactorily explained the discrepancy of quasiparticle band gaps between previous ab initio calculations and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy measurements. Second, the PI’s group has finished calculations of excited-state properties and thermal transport properties of a newly emerging 2D material, few-layer black phosphorus, as shown in Figures 2 and 3. These works have accurately predicted the band gap and anisotropic optical, thermal responses of black phosphorus. Most of these predictions have been confirmed by subsequent experiments and have motivated more works on this field. Third, the PI’s group has calculated the band offsets between monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides, based quasiparticle energies. This provides the fundamental information to understand the transport performance and electron-hole pair dissociations in 2D heterojunctions. Fourth, the PI’s group has predicted unusually giant piezoelectric effects in a new family of 2D materials, monolayer group IV chalcogenides, as summarized in Figure 4. Using the modern theory of polarization, this work has shown that their piezoelectric coefficients can be two orders of magnitude larger than other known piezoelectric materials.

 

Broad impacts:  The developed efficient ab initio approach to calculate band gaps of doped 2D semiconductors provides a novel tool for designing and controlling the fundamental band gap and subsequent transport and optical properties of few-layer semiconducting structures. The calculations of band offsets of transition metal dichalcogenides pave the way for realizing semiconducting heterostructures for device applications. The studies of black phosphorus predict promising electronic and energy applications because of the unusually anisotropic transport properties and high thermoelectric figure of merit. The prediction of giant piezoelectric effects in monolayer group IV chalcogenides opens the door for high-efficient nano-scale electric generators, which are of broad interests for portable electronics and flexible devices. Finally, the PI’s group has successfully helped three graduate students for obtaining their PhD degrees and one undergraduate student for the summer research opportunity. This NSF support also makes it possible for involved researchers to attend academic conferences and giving talks and posters to present our research achievements.
